abstract.para: Using &cockpit;, you can change the host name, set or synchronize the system time or change a time zone.

section.title: Viewing system health
section.para: To view the system health, click Overview on the left pane. You can view the following details in the Health section.
If a service fails, you can click the 1 service failed to view the details of the service failure.
Click View login history to view your login history. You can modify the user credentials in the user page.

section.title: Viewing metrics and history
section.para: You can view the PCP metrics and usage history under Usage section in the Overview page.

listitem.para: Click Overview on the left pane.
The following details appear in the Metrics and History page.
CPU - The number of CPUs, the CPU load and a list of services that utilize the CPU.
Memory - The RAM and Swap memory usage, and the related services.
Disks - A list of used disks and partitions. Click View per-disk throughput to display a table showing the data transfer rates for each disk.
Network - Displays the list of networks.

Metrics history - When present, &cockpit; integrates with the Performance Co-Pilot (PCP) framework to collect and manage system performance metrics. These metrics are used to render historical data visualizations on the Metrics and history interface. &cockpit; can also utilize the archive logging subsystem of PCP to retrieve and display time-shifted historical data. In environments where PCP is not installed, &cockpit; falls back to its own metrics collection mechanism; however, this mode does not support data archival or retrieval of historical metrics.
Archival of metrics depends on whether the pmlogger.service systemd unit is running or not. You can enable the Collect metrics option to enable and start the service.

section.title: Changing the server host name
section.para: To change the host name, proceed as follows:

step.para: In the Configuration section, click edit under Hostname.

listitem.para: Pretty host name—a user-defined free-form host name
Real host name—the name of the device in the network

section.title: Changing the system time or time zone
section.para: To change the system time or time zone, proceed as follows:

procedure.title: Changing system time or time zone

step.para: In the Configuration section, click the current time value underSystem time.
In the pop-up window you can change the following:

listitem.para: Time zone—the value set during the manual installation or, in case of raw images, set to UTC.
Set time—by default, NTP is used for time synchronization. You can set the time manually or, if you defined alternative NTP servers, you can use those NTP servers for time synchronization.
Click Change.

section.title: Changing the cryptographic policy
section.para: To change the cryptographic policy, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click Default next to Cryptographic policy.
In the pop-up window, click on one of the following policy types:

listitem.para: It allows the TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 protocols, as well as IKEv2 and SSH2. The Diffie-Hellman parameters are accepted if they are at least 2048 bits long. The level provides at least 112-bit security with the exception of allowing SHA-1 signatures in DNSSEC, where they are still prevalent.
Is a subpolicy of the default that enables using the SHA-1 algorithm.

This policy ensures maximum compatibility with legacy systems. It is less secure and includes support for TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 and SSH2 protocols or later. The algorithms DSA, 3DES and RC4 are allowed, while RSA and Diffie-Hellman parameters are accepted if larger than 1023 bits. The level provides at least 64-bit security.
Is a subpolicy of LEGACY with Active Directory interoperability.

A level that conforms to the FIPS 140-2 requirements. This policy is used internally by the fips-mode-setup tool that can switch the system into the FIPS 140-2 compliance mode. The level provides at least 112-bit security.
A subpolicy of FIPS with further Common Criteria restrictions.

A conservative security level that is believed to withstand any near-term future attacks. This level does not allow the use of SHA-1 in signature algorithms. The level also provides some (not complete) preparation for post-quantum encryption support as a 256-bit symmetric encryption requirement. The RSA and Diffie-Hellman parameters are accepted if larger than 3071 bits. This level provides at least 128-bit security.

step.para: To apply the changes, click Apply and reboot.
